text: Hey there Head Squeezers and Whovians!

Hope you're well; yes it is the 50th anniversary
of when the Doctor first appeared on our screens.

So here on Head Squeeze we thought we'd make
a whole week worth of videos tied to the man
himself.
Hello Sir!
Nice to meet you!

So we put out a call on Twitter and Facebook
for your Doctor Who related questions and

the one I've picked is from KittenVonPink
who sent a brilliant one in on Twitter.
Which is can Humans Have Two Hearts?
Great question Kitten.

So of course the Doctor as a Time Lord has
a Binary Vascular System, but then again he
is an extra-terrestrial.

So what us humans, well first of all our single
human heart is pretty impressive by itself.

It's beating while you're chilling out there
sitting or standing there watching this video
about 60-80 times a minute.

Which add that up over an average lifetime
means your heart will beat about three billion
times.
Amazing!
So, are there any humans that have two hearts?

Well conjoined twins sometimes have two hearts
but as well as them there are some people

that do indeed have two hearts but they're
not born with them.
It comes from an extreme case of cardiomyopathy.

Now what you'd normally do is pop in a donor
heart and remove that weakened original heart

but sometimes the safest thing to do is to
actually graft the donor heart on to the chambers
and vessels that are already there.

This means that the donor heart now called
a piggy back heart does the majority of the

pumping but the original heart also pumps
but with less pressure with less strain on
it.

Bonus fact, there are other creatures that
have more than one heart and they're not even
from Gallifrey.
I'm talking about the octopus.

It has one main systemic heart that pumps
blood to the whole of its body but then it

also has two additional hearts one responsible
for pumping to each of its gills.
A bit of a show off don't you think?

Anyway, that's all the time I've got right
now.
Until next time happy Head Squeezing.
